<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 235, 175, 247]]<|/det|> NUMBER <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 170, 291]]<|/det|> **PHYSICS** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 280, 905, 291]]<|/det|> **0625/53** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 905, 312]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test **October/November 2011** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 320, 905, 333]]<|/det|> **1 hour 15 minutes** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 341, 411, 354]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 361, 581, 373]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 395, 386, 408]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 421, 781, 435]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 327, 448]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 578, 463]]<|/det|> You may use a pencil for any diagrams, graphs or rough working. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 598, 477]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 478, 384, 491]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 505, 255, 517]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 604, 546]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 547, 759, 560]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 655, 907, 850]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 875, 737, 888]]<|/det|> This document consists of **10** printed pages and **2** blank pages. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 903, 620, 915]]<|/det|> DC (SJF/CGW) 34205/2 UNIVERSITY of CAMBRIDGE <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 914, 620, 926]]<|/det|> © UCLES 2011 International Examinations **[Turn over**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 808, 92]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the density of modelling clay by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 243, 122]]<|/det|>
Method 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 878, 170]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.1. You are provided with a piece of modelling clay.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[288, 178, 662, 306]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 322, 510, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 181, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 873, 388]]<|/det|>
Mould the piece of modelling clay into a shape that is approximately a cube. Measure the height \(h\), width \(w\) and depth \(d\) of the piece of modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 399, 873, 419]]<|/det|>
<form>h = ................................................. cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 431, 873, 450]]<|/det|>
<form>w = ................................................. cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 460, 873, 480]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ................................................. cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 492, 181, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 491, 870, 512]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the piece of modelling clay using the equation \(V = hwd.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 568, 875, 588]]<|/det|>
<form>V = ................................................. cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 600, 178, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 599, 848, 620]]<|/det|>
Measure the mass \(m\) of the piece of modelling clay using the balance provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 631, 875, 650]]<|/det|>
<form>m = ................................................. g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 662, 183, 681]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 661, 781, 682]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m}{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 787, 875, 807]]<|/det|>
<form>ρ = ................................................. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 242, 91]]<|/det|>
Method 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 853, 139]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.2. You are provided with a beaker containing water at room temperature.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 144, 630, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 374, 512, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 405, 875, 441]]<|/det|>
Break the piece of modelling clay into two pieces with one piece approximately twice the size of the other piece.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 181, 471]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 452, 724, 472]]<|/det|>
Using the **smaller** piece of modelling clay, measure its mass \(m_{\mathrm{s}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 483, 873, 503]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{s}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 514, 181, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 513, 875, 549]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume of water \(V_{1}\) in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 560, 871, 580]]<|/det|>
\[V_{1} = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 590, 180, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 590, 875, 642]]<|/det|>
Tie the thread around the smaller piece of modelling clay and lower it into the measuring cylinder until it is completely covered with water. Record the new volume \(V_{2}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 653, 871, 672]]<|/det|>
\[V_{2} = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 685, 181, 703]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 685, 834, 704]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{s}} = V_{2} - V_{1}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 761, 871, 781]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{s}} = ............................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 792, 181, 811]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 791, 781, 816]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the modelling clay using the equation \(\rho = \frac{m_{\mathrm{s}}}{V_{\mathrm{s}}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 902, 875, 922]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho =\) .................................................... [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 816, 107]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the energy changes that occur when hot water are mixed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 863, 139]]<|/det|>
You are provided with a supply of hot water and a supply of cold (room temperature) water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 148, 875, 184]]<|/det|>
Pour \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the beaker labelled \(\mathbf{A}\). Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{c}}\) of this water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 196, 873, 216]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{c}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 227, 181, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 225, 875, 261]]<|/det|>
Pour \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker labelled \(\mathbf{B}\). Measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{h}}\) of this water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 272, 871, 292]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{h}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 303, 181, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 875, 355]]<|/det|>
As soon as you have taken the temperature, pour the \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water from beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) into beaker \(\mathbf{B}\). Briefly stir the mixture then measure and record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{m}}\) of the mixture.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 365, 875, 386]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{\mathrm{m}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 382, 875, 401]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 144, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 180, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 412, 816, 432]]<|/det|>
Calculate the gain in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) of the cold water using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 428, 539, 448]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{c}} = k(\theta_{\mathrm{m}} - \theta_{\mathrm{c}})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 444, 361, 463]]<|/det|>
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 507, 871, 528]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{c}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 539, 183, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 537, 806, 558]]<|/det|>
Calculate the loss in thermal energy \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) of the hot water using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 555, 541, 575]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{h}} = k(\theta_{\mathrm{h}} - \theta_{\mathrm{m}})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 570, 361, 588]]<|/det|>
where \(k = 210 \text{J} /\text{°C}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 635, 875, 655]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{h}} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 651, 875, 670]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 675, 144, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 674, 875, 710]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that all the thermal energy lost by the hot water is gained by the cold water. \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) and \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\) should therefore be equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 721, 181, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 721, 875, 755]]<|/det|>
State whether your experimental results support this suggestion and justify your statement by reference to your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 766, 871, 787]]<|/det|>
statement ..................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 797, 871, 817]]<|/det|>
justification ..................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 828, 875, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>.....................................................................................................................[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 860, 181, 878]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 860, 850, 880]]<|/det|>
Suggest a practical reason in this experiment why \(E_{\mathrm{c}}\) might be different from \(E_{\mathrm{h}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 892, 875, 911]]<|/det|>
<form>....................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 808, 91]]<|/det|> Another student was asked to suggest quantities that should be kept constant <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 87, 828, 103]]<|/det|> experiment is repeated in order to check the readings. Table 2.1 shows the suggest <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 851, 135]]<|/det|> Place a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the second column of the table next to each correctly suggests quantity. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 150, 515, 168]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 180, 756, 373]]<|/det|>
suggestion
avoid parallax errors when taking readings
number of stirs
room temperature
starting temperature of cold water
starting temperature of hot water
use only two or three significant figures for the final answers
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 361, 876, 380]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[789, 390, 876, 408]]<|/det|> [Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 631, 92]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 452, 122]]<|/det|> You will use the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 129, 734, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 402, 509, 421]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 144, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 433, 178, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 433, 878, 469]]<|/det|> Switch on. Measure and record in Table 3.1 the current \(I\) in the circuit and the p.d. \(V\) across a length \(l = 0.250 \text{m}\) of the wire \(\mathbf{PQ}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1. Switch off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 473, 185, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 834, 494]]<|/det|> Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the length \(l = 0.250 \text{m}\) of wire using the equation <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 497, 512, 529]]<|/det|> \[R = \frac{V}{I}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 534, 480, 553]]<|/det|> Record this value of \(R\) in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 560, 180, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 560, 714, 580]]<|/det|> Repeat steps (i) and (ii) using \(l\) values of \(0.500 \text{m}\) and \(0.750 \text{m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 585, 180, 604]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 585, 616, 604]]<|/det|> Complete the heading for each column of the table. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 616, 517, 635]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 648, 732, 761]]<|/det|>
\(l/\)\(V/\)\(I/\)\(R/\)
0.250
0.500
0.750
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 747, 876, 765]]<|/det|> [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 819, 92]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the formation of images by a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 566, 123]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig 4.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 133, 803, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 272, 509, 291]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 146, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 304, 185, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 303, 663, 322]]<|/det|> Place the screen about \(1.0 \text{m}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 329, 180, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 327, 875, 378]]<|/det|> Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the centre of the lens is at a distance \(u = 0.200 \text{m}\) from the object. Adjust the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 384, 180, 403]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 384, 873, 403]]<|/det|> Measure (in metres) the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 410, 180, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 409, 541, 428]]<|/det|> Record the values of \(u\) and \(v\) in Table 4.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 181, 454]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 435, 875, 469]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps in (i) – (iv) using values for \(u\) of \(0.250 \text{m}\), \(0.300 \text{m}\), \(0.350 \text{m}\) and \(0.400 \text{m}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 482, 517, 500]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 512, 761, 686]]<|/det|>
\(u/\mathrm {m}\)\(v/\mathrm {m}\)\(\frac {1}{u}/\frac {1}{\mathrm {m}}\)\(\frac {1}{v}/\frac {1}{\mathrm {m}}\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 712, 181, 731]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 707, 707, 737]]<|/det|> Calculate the values of \(\frac{1}{u}\) and \(\frac{1}{v}\) and enter them in the table.
